text.p: The United States condemned on Thursday "in the strongest terms" a series of killings of foreigners in Rwanda over the past three weeks.

Attackers ambushed and killed four U.N. human rights monitors near the southwestern town of Cyangugu on Tuesday. Three Spanish aid workers were killed in the northwestern town of Ruhengeri on Jan. 18 and a 61-year-old Canadian missionary was shot dead by a lone gunman on Sunday in Ruhengeri prefecture.

State Department spokesman Nicholas Buns implicitly blamed what he called "genocidal elements" of the former Rwandan army and Interahamwe militiamen for these and other attacks in the central African country, torn apart by a civil war in 1994.
"The United States condemns in the strongest terms the terrorist attacks against Rwandans and expatriates in Rwanda," Burns said in a statement.
"We urge all Rwandans to put aside their differences, end the ceaseless violence, and work towards peace, justice and reconciliation in their country."
